questions.question: Person-first language (person with autism) is preferred by most autistic people.

questions.title: Many Autistic people prefer identity-first.
questions.description: This positions autism as an identity category not an illness or affliction - thatâ€™s why we use it in this quiz! Different people have different preferences. Always listen to how someone refers to themselves and follow their lead.

questions.question: You shouldn't capitalize autism because it's a common noun.

questions.title: Many people capitalize Autism.
questions.description: This is because capitalising Autism asserts that Autism is an identity and a community. This is why we may write it as either in our quizzes. Always capitalise the 'a' if you refer to the 'Autistic community'.

questions.question: Autistic people can't be neurodivergent in multple ways (like by being Dyslexic or having ADHD or Tourette's Syndrome).

questions.title: Multiple types of neurodivergence are common!
questions.description: One 2014 study found that 30-50% of people on the autism spectrum also had ADHD traits & up to 50% are dyspraxic. Further, just like allistic people, autistic people may have co-morbid mental, developmental, or physical health diagnoses.

questions.title: Important info for the next question:
questions.description: Synesthetes, people experience synesthesia, experience that information that stimulates one sense for non-synesthetes stimulates two or several for them. Synesthetes may see sounds, taste words, feel a sensation when they smell certain scents, etc.

questions.question: Autistic people are up to ten times more likely than non-autistic people to experience synesthesia.
Some Autistic people are nonverbal or nonspeaking. This means that they cannot communicate.

questions.title: Nonverbal and nonspeaking people can communicate!
questions.description: Through sign language, augmented communication tools, sounds, and more, nonverbal and nonspeaking people communicate. It's up to all of us to make sure that there are the resources, time, and space to ensure that everyone is listened to!

questions.title: Want to learn more?!
questions.description: Head to our blog to read on about autism, ADHD, and neurodiversity https://www.tiimoapp.com/blog/
